item.title: Henri Bergius
item.description:
Henri Bergius

Hacker and an occasional adventurer. Author of Create.js and NoFlo. Decoupling software, one piece at a time.

item.title: For the second time, we are witnessing a new geological epoch
item.description:
For the second time, we are witnessing a new geological epoch

11,700 years ago, the Earth suffered a catastrophic climate change. As the ice age ended, sea levels rose by 120 meters, the days grew warmer, and many kinds of plant and animal life died out. But one animal began to thrive more than ever before.

item.title: A new robot life preserver joins rescue efforts for refugees in Europe
item.description:
A new robot life preserver joins rescue efforts for refugees in Europe

The European refugee crisis isn't so much a crisis as it is a catastrophe. Fleeing violence in Africa and the Middle East, particularly Syria, more than a million migrants crossed by sea into Europe in 2015. Almost 4,000 of them lost their lives in the journey.

item.title: Why I carry a Newton
item.description:
Why I carry a Newton

A Newton MessagePad, the grandfather of all PDAs, is a funny thing to carry around with you when most people are sliding super slim, constantly connected, application-rich smartphones into their pockets. Compared to the iPhone a Newton MessagePad looks like a green brick, and I have been accused more than once of stealing the rubberized signature pad from a UPS delivery man.

item.title: Apploitation in a city of instaserfs
item.description:
Apploitation in a city of instaserfs

If you spend enough time in San Francisco, you'll notice sharing economy workers everywhere. While you're waiting to get some food, look for the most frantic person in the lineup and you can bet they're working with an app.

item.title: Space Oddity
item.description:
Space Oddity

A revised version of David Bowie's Space Oddity, recorded by Commander Chris Hadfield on board the International Space Station.

item.title: The top A.I. breakthroughs of 2015
item.description:
The top A.I. breakthroughs of 2015

Progress in artificial intelligence and machine learning has been impressive this year. Those in the field acknowledge progress is accelerating year by year, though it is still a manageable pace for us. The vast majority of work in the field these days actually builds on previous work done by other teams earlier the same year, in contrast to most other fields where references span decades.

item.title: How papermaking crossed the Alps
item.description:
How papermaking crossed the Alps

Writing has been an important medium for recording and transmitting scientific results throughout history. In order to write you need two basic things, something to write with and something to write on. Carving words or symbols into wood or stone is one possibility that is both hard work and time consuming but does have the...

item.title: Japan Keeps This Defunct Train Station Running for Just One Passenger
item.description:
Japan Keeps This Defunct Train Station Running for Just One Passenger

For years, there’s only been one passenger waiting at the Kami-Shirataki train station in the northernmost island of Hokkaido, Japan: A high-school girl, on her way to class. The train stops there only twice a day—once to pick up the girl and again to drop her off after the school day is over.

item.title: Decentralization as a Strategy
item.description:
Decentralization as a Strategy

Can Dapps actually be profitable? If your code is free, and your data is free, what left is there to sell? Vitalik Buterin thinks that there is no killer Dapp. Instead, he sees Dapps as having marginally better qualities among certain dimensions, like uptime and automation - and marginally worse qualities along other dimensions like privacy and speed.
